description: Flowers in heads; usually yellow, but can be orange, red, purple or white. Leaves pinnate with narrow leaflets, finely haired
distribution: Found in open grassland
phenology: April - September, although May - July best

description: Flowers blue, on thin stalks in loose clusters. 5 petals. Lowest leaves roundish with a few teeth, upper leaves narrow, untoothed and unstalked
distribution: Found in short, grazed grassland

description: Flowers bright yellow, 5 petals and star-shaped, found singularly at the end of stalks. Leaves cylindrical, reddish to green.
distribution: Found on dry, bare places, usually rock

description: Flowers dark blue-purple, sometimes pink, in rounded heads. Leaves elliptical, untoothed and often stalked
distribution: Damp, grassy places like dune slacks

description: Flowers whitish or pale pink, flower heads stalked and egg-shaped, distinctively covered in hairs. Trefoil leaves, narrow, oval leaflets with short hairs
distribution: Dry grassland and sandy soils

description: Tufted, triangular flowerhead made of clumps of flowers. Mostly green, with purple-red ends. Leaves grey-green.
distribution: Grassland. Grows up to 140cm tall

description: Flowers yellow, 5 petals, at the end of stems. Leaves pinnate, toothed and often silvery in colour.
distribution: Creeping along the ground, often in trampled disturbed ground and damp areas

description: Flower white, in globe-shaped heads, occasionally pale pink. Trefoil leaves with rounded leaflets, often with white markings
distribution: Common on all grassland, growing low to the ground. Favoured flower of bees

description: Flower heads dense, flowers green to red in colour. Leaves long and narrow, with strongly waved margins. Often pointed.
distribution: Often on disturbed ground or near water, although can be found almost anywhere. Grows up to 1m tall
confusion: Broad leaved dock (Rumex obtusifolius), Copmmon sorrel (Rumex acetosa)

description: Lilac flowers, in clusters, flowerheads sometimes branched. Bracts purpleish in colour. Leaves pinnately lobed, sometimes cottony on the underside, stems spineless.
distribution: Grassy areas and wasteland, cultivated ground, grows up to 1.2m
confusion: Spear thistle (Cirsium vulgare), Marsh thistle (Cirsium palustre)

description: Flowerheds yellow and clustered. Leaves long and pinnately lobed with soft, spiny margins.
distribution: Early coloniser of bare & waste ground, found in areas of bare sand. Marsh sow-thistle found in marshes & ditches.

description: Low, creeping, moss-like plant with opposing pairs of fleshy, cylindrical leaves. Leaves red towards the base of stems, turning to green towards the tips. White flowers, usually with 3 petals, occasionally 4
distribution: Disturbed ground, bare and rocky areas

description: Slender grass, up to 30cm tall. Bristle-like grey-green leaves.
distribution: Frequently on bare, dry ground as well as rocky outcrops

description: White-tinged red flowerheads, which can also appear yellow. Star-like flowers in clusters at top of plant. Leaves small and pointed, held close to the stem, and with silvery hairs.
distribution: Open, sandy or gravelly areas

description: Short, tuft-forming rush. Grass-like leaves, fringed with long, white hairs. Flowers brown, forming rounded clusters towards the top of stems
distribution: Grassy areas, growing up to 25cm tall

description: Dense, upright flowerheads, with all flowers growing from one side. Red-tipped green, changing to orange-brown when mature. Simple, broad leaves
distribution: Open, disturbed areas on fixed dunes, and sandy shingle

description: Flowers greenish-yellow to pale brown, in tall, narrow stalks. Leaves broad, pointed ovals with thin stems down to base.
distribution: Regularly disturbed areas, particularly well-trodden places, as leaves are resistant to trampling

description: Long, thin leaves, growing in clusters of 6-8 around the stem, coated in small, sticky hooks which attach to fur or clothing. Small, dull white flowers with 4 petals, growing on stalks from the base of the leaves.
distribution: Often growing alongside other plants, using them for support. Often found in hedges, or areas of scrub where the sward is higher.

description: Leaves glossy, curled and cylindrical but can be unrolled. Tall and pointed. Flower spikes densely packed, golden to light brown in colour
distribution: Thick tufts of marram are found on embryo dunes and areas of bare sand, where it helps to hold the dunes together

description: Thin, wiry leaves, growing up to 35cm tall. Flower spikes with pale brown spikelets, carrying flowers in dense clusters
distribution: On embryo dunes and areas of bare sand, this is an early coloniser

description: Blue flowers in globe-shaped heads with narrow petals. Somewhat scruffy looking. Leaves oblong and narrow, sometimes wavy-edged and hairy
distribution: Dry, grassy areas and heaths, particularly areas with sandy soil

description: Solitary, bright yellow flowerheads above purple-tipped bracts. Leaves growing in a rosette at the base, lance-like with wavy edges, blunted ends and bearing small hairs
distribution: Dry grassland, wasteland and often the edges of car parks

description: Generally pale green in colour, they are mostly distinguished by the fruiting body cups, which are often raised above the lichen on stalks.
distribution: Trees, Rocks, Fallen branches

description: Bluish-green shiny moss, growing in dense mats up to 10cm tall. Leaves narrow, light green but tipped with red. Leaves radiating from central stem in a star shape
distribution: Dry, acidic soil on heaths, and on rocks & walls

description: Palmate leaves with 5 lobes, usually 7-16cm across, slightly toothed margins. Flowers are green-yellow in colour, and hang in clusters from the end of branches.
distribution: Almost everywhere. Woodland and areas of scrub in particular
confusion: Field maple (Acer campestre), Norway maple (Acer platanoides)

description: Dark green, glossy, oval shaped leaves. Spiky leaves on younger trees, but these are less common on older ones. Flowers white with 4 petals, occurring in clusters.
distribution: Common in woodland and areas of scrub
phenology: Variable flowering time - early spring to early summer, depending on yearly temperatures

description: Evergreen with blue-green needles, which are often slightly twisted. Needles grow in pairs. Male flowers grow as small, yellow clusters at the base of shoots, female flowers are small, reddish-purple and globe shaped, growing at the tip of shoots
distribution: Areas of scrub or heath in particular

description: Stubby moss, with stems up to 5cm in length, but usually shorter. Dark green to dark brown-black when dry. Leaves straight when wet, radiating out in a star shape
distribution: Pioneer species on recently disturbed ground, but will also grow on fences, rotten wood and shingle

description: Distinctive plantain with pinnate leaves growing in a rosette at the base, somewhat resembling antlers. Flower spikes yellow-brown with protruding anthers.
distribution: Dry, bare, sandy places, particularly frequently disturbed areas like edges of paths
confusion: Nothing. Other plantains at a push
comments: Fixed dune acidic grassland positive indicators

description: Very thin leaves, rolling in at the margins, growing up to 40cm tall. Straw coloured when mature. Erect flowerheads with flowers along one side, giving a bushy appearance
distribution: Dry areas, particularly banks, gravelly areas, walls and dry heath
comments: Fixed dune acidic grassland positive indicators

description: Sharply spined thistle with deeply lobed pinnate leaves. Flowerheads lilac, 2-4cm across and quite puffy, with a spiny ball-like bracts below. Stems somewhat cottony
distribution: Disturbed ground, particularly verges and field edges, as well as waste ground.
confusion: Other thistles, particularly Cotton thistle (Onopordum acanthium)
comments: Fixed dune acidic grassland negative indicators

description: Thin, thorny stems. Pinnate leaves with toothed margins. Flowers often large, usually white, pink or red with large, floppy petals which detach easily.
distribution: Usually found in scrub or hedgerows, except Burnet rose (Rosa pimpinellifolia) which grows in open areas across heath and dunes with short grass
comments: Fixed dune acidic grassland negative indicators

description: Evergreen shrub growing to 2.5m, leaves short, firm spines, stalked towards the base. Yellow, lipped flowers growing from the base of the spines towards the end of branches, strongly coconut scented
distribution: Heaths and grassland, particularly ungrazed areas
confusion: Dwarf gorse (Ulex minor), Western gorse (Ulex gallii)
comments: Fixed dune acidic grassland negative indicators

description: Carpeting heather, usually growing up to 50cm, occasionally downy in appearance. Oblong leaves in alternate rows, branching from the main stem. Flowers pale pink to mauve, growing in spikes at the end of stems.
distribution: Anywhere on dunes and heathland, except particularly wet areas, can often be found dominating large areas
confusion: Other heathers, especially Bell heather (Erica cinerea)
comments: Fixed dune acidic grassland negative indicators

description: Short, creeping plant with lobed, pinnate leaves and deep pink, hooked burs which turn bronze coloured. Small, cream coloured flowers grow on spherical heads atop upright stalks.
distribution: Wet slopes, dunes and grassy areas, forming a dense mat at ground level
comments: Fixed dune acidic grassland negative indicators

description: Shrub with dense, dark green, leathery, oval leaves. Blooms large, ranging from light pink to purple, with open, bell-shaped flowers of 5 petals
distribution: Once rhododendron takes hold, little else can grow because of the dense canopy, so it is often found in areas of shrub
comments: Fixed dune acidic grassland negative indicators

description: Creeping, greeny-yellow plant with fleshy, oval leaves. Flowers with 5 petals, small and greenish-white with a yellow centre. Flowers solitary and at the end of stems
distribution: Areas of sand and shingle, growing low to the ground
comments: Mobile dune acidic grassland positive indicators

description: Small, bushy plant with linear, succulent leaves with sharp, prickly tips. Solitary green flowers, above leaf-like bracts
distribution: Areas of bare sand,
comments: Mobile dune acidic grassland positive indicators

description: Greyish-green, hairless succulent, lobed, pinnate leaves towards the base and more linear leaves moving up the stem. Flowers with 4 petals, pale lilac to white in colour
distribution: Sandy coastal areas
comments: Mobile dune acidic grassland positive indicators

description: Large, trumpet shaped flowers, light pink in colour, with white stripes. Fleshy, kidney-shaped leaves, with stems creeping along the ground
distribution: Bare, sandy areas, growing amongst marram grass
confusion: Hedge bindweed (Calystegia sepium), Field bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis), Great bindweed (Calystegia silvatica)
comments: Mobile dune acidic grassland positive indicators

description: Green stems and narrow, blade-like leaves. The spikelets, which hold the flowers, are attached to the stem in an alternating pattern.
distribution: Roadside verges, rough pastures and waste ground

description: A deciduous bushy shrub. 1m tall – 2m wide. Narrowly-oval, densely-hairy leaves are grey-green above and silvery beneath and appear after the silvery catkins that mature to yellow in spring.
distribution: Sand dunes, acid grassland and heathland including coastal heaths.
confusion: Hybridised willow species typically including goat willow (S. caprea) and downy willow (S. lapponum).

description: Hairy, oval, toothed leaves that appear in whorls around the reddish stems. It produces dense clusters of lilac-pink flowers at the ends of its stems.
distribution: Freshwater Wetlands, Towns and Gardens

description: Leaves are peltate, having a roughly circular shape and frequently a comparatively long petiole. The flower stems are shorter than the petioles and bare tiny, pinkish flowers
distribution: Aquatic weed that spreads out horizontally forming dense mats in shallow water, mud, or in marshes.
confusion: The leaves are similar to Navelwort but this is found in much dryer habitats such as walls and quarries.

description: Selfheal is a low-growing, perennial herb with paired, oval leaves and bluish or violet flowers that appear in dense, oblong clusters on the top of its stems. Its purple-tinged seed head remains after flowering
distribution: Short turf of grasslands, uncut grass in woodlands, roadside verges, lawns

description: Bog pimpernel is low growing. The flowers are small, pink and cup-shaped with five petals. The leaves are small, rounded and in pairs along thin wiry stems.
distribution: wet, open meadows and fens
phenology: Pink flowers are out in June and July

description: Rounded, blue flower heads. It has silvery-blue leaves with many prickly spikes on their edges.
distribution: Coastal

description: A relatively tall-growing plant that has clusters of yellow, flattened flower heads, and leaves that are very divided.
distribution: Abundant
comments: Mobile dune negative indicator & Dune slacks negative indicator

description: A herbaceous perennial flowering plant. 1 to 2 m (3 to 7 ft) tall in the summer and dying down to the ground in winter. Soft green leaves with strongly serrated margins and small, greenish or brownish flowers.
distribution: Abundant
comments: Mobile dune negative indicator, Fixed dune grassland negative indicator & Dune slack negative indicator

description: A member of the pea family. Yellow flowers that appear in small clusters. They are followed by seed pods that look distinctly like bird's feet or claws, hence the common name. A low-growing plant, its leaves have five leaflets and are downy.
distribution: Grassland, heathland, moorland, sand dunes, rocky habitat, coastal, towns and gardens
comments: Dune slack positive indicator, Fixed dune positive indicator,

description: A common fern growing in dense stands. Large, branched fronds which appear in spring and are green when mature, but die back to brown
distribution: Abundant

description: A large, deciduous shrub that has long, narrow, greyish leaves and small, green flowers. It has bright orange berries.
distribution: Coastal, sand dunes

description: Creeping buttercup can be distinguished from the other buttercups by the spreading way it grows with runners. Yellow flowers are about 2cm across and its hairy leaves are divided into three lobes with frayed edges.
distribution: Grassland, wetland, towns and gardens, farmland, woodland

description: Has oval, pointed leaves that are yellowy-green in colour. Purple flowers, with protruding yellow stamens, bright red, cherry tomato-like berries that hang in clusters.
distribution: Freshwater, farmland, woodlands, towns and gardens
confusion: Other members of the nightshade family

description: Small, narrow leaves that appear in whorls on its angular stems. The stems carry frothy heads of tiny, yellow flowers that appear in dense clusters.
distribution: Grassland, heathland and moorland, farmland, coastal, towns and gardens

description: Has oval, sharply toothed leaves, and white, violet-like flowers that have purple veins and yellow centres.
distribution: Grassland, Heathland and Moorland, Coastal
confusion: Other species of Eyebright and hybrids

description: Has yellow, tube-like flowers protruding from an inflated, green calyx. It has serrated leaves with heavy, dark veins, which sprout opposite each other all the way up the stem. Its stems have black spots.
distribution: Grassland, farmland

description: Bramble has long, thorny and arching stems and can grow up to two metres or more high,alternate and palmately compound. Each leaf is divided into three or five serrated, short-stalked, oval leaflets. Leaves are dark green on top and pale beneath. Leaf stalks and mid-ribs are prickly,clusters of white or pink flowers appear from late spring to early summer. They are 2–3cm in diameter with five petals and many stamens.
distribution: Woodland, grassland

description: Leaves: pinnately compound, with three to five leaflets which are elliptical in shape with rough toothed margins. Leaves grow in an opposite leaf arrangement.  Flowers: white in colour, the various stamens are clearly visible and the flowers are in clusters. The flowers are around two centimetres in width. Although they appear to have four petals, they are in fact sepals. Seed clusters which have a feathered appearance and are white-grey in colour. They are called achenes. It is the fruit which gives the plant its other name: 'old man’s beard'.
distribution: Hedgerow

description: Forms green, yellow-green or occasionally orange-brown patches. Shoots are commonly 3 to 8 cm long, often red towards the base. Main stem usually erect, side branches pinnately arranged, whole shoot having a flattened appearance. Leaves closely rolled-up to form a smooth needle-like or spear-like point. Stem leaves are usually 2 to 2.5 mm long, narrowly egg-shaped, never curved, bluntly rounded at the tip.
distribution: Common in moist, base-rich habitats, such as marshes, mires and flushes, in grassland, and among rocks. It also occurs in relatively dry places in calcareous habitats, such as chalk and limestone grassland

description: Erect, pale or yellow-green, shoots typically 2–3 cm long. Stem leaves strongly curved away from the stem, often at right angles to it, giving the shoots a star-like appearance when seen from above.
distribution: Slightly base-rich mires, flushes and dune slacks, sometimes over wet rocks in open places.

description: Creeping perennial about 10 to 40cm tall. It has an upper spike of female flowers and two male spikes lower down the stem. The purplish-brown flowers are followed by reddish black seeds. Bluish-grey blush found on the underside of the leaves.
distribution: Frequent in a range of habitats, including grasslands, moorlands, exposed and disturbed soil, and the upper edges of salt marshes

description: Medium to tall hairy plant. Stem erect often reddish. Leaves opposite, deeply 3-5 lobed, leaflets coarsely toothed. Flowerheads pink or purplish 2 to 5 mm in dense rather flat topped clusters, florets all tubular.
distribution: damp grassland, marshes, fens and wet woodlands, and along riverbanks

description: Perennial . Member of the dead-nettle family not closely related to Ivy. It is an evergreen, creeping plant spreading by means of overground runners that frequently root. It has a strong smell and violet flowers. kidney-shaped, deep green leaves are typically scalloped and slightly undulating at the margins upper leaf surface has a covering of very small bristly hairs. stems are square, and have opposite pairs of simple leaves. Ground ivy's stems are also covered in fine bristly hairs.
distribution: woodlands, hedgerows and damp ground
confusion: purple dead nettle; henbit dead nettle
